qas.question: When was the patent case Davoll et al. v. Brown ruled on?
Which court ruled on the patent case Davoll et al. v. Brown?
Who wrote that "only in this way can we protect intellectual property"?
What year did the "discoveries are property" concept appear in French law?
When did French author A. Nion mention intellectual property?
What French author mentioned intellectual property in 1845?
Who ruled on the 1846 patent case?
What justice wrote "All new discoveries are the property of the author"
In what year did French law state that " the labors of the mind, productions and interests are as much a man's own...as the wheat he cultivates"?
What is delivered to the nventor for anywhere from 1-15 years?

context: The term can be found used in an <a0_0>October 1845<a0_0/> <a1_0><b6_0>Massachusetts Circuit Court<b6_0/><a1_0/> ruling in the patent case Davoll et al. v. Brown., in which <a2_0><b7_0>Justice Charles L. Woodbury<b7_0/><a2_0/> wrote that "only in this way can we protect intellectual property, the labors of the mind, productions and interests are as much a man's own...as the wheat he cultivates, or the flocks he rears." The statement that "discoveries are...property" goes back earlier. Section 1 of the French law of <a3_0><b8_0>1791<b8_0/><a3_0/> stated, "All new discoveries are the property of the author; to assure the inventor the property and temporary enjoyment of his discovery, there shall be delivered to him <b9_0>a patent<b9_0/> for five, ten or fifteen years." In Europe, French author <b5_0>A. Nion<b5_0/> mentioned propriété intellectuelle in his Droits civils des auteurs, artistes et inventeurs, published in <a4_0>1846<a4_0/>.
